awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, the University of Arkansas, Little Rock (UALR) is working with Henderson Middle School, UALR Children's International and the Museum of Discovery to recruit 40 undergraduate students majoring in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) disciplines and prepare them to become secondary school teachers. Additionally, internships will support five first and second-year students in informal science settings to provide them with early teaching experiences. Upon completion of licensure, Noyce teachers will be supported by biannual UALRTeach Professional Development Days during induction, and work primarily in the high-needs Little Rock School District.

Arkansas is in particular need of STEM trained professionals due to the overall shortfall in college degrees within the state which contribute to severe shortages in STEM areas, and the UALRTeach program will respond to this need through the preparation of highly-qualified STEM secondary teachers. Underrepresented students will be targeted for recruitment into the UALRTeach program to increase the diversity of secondary STEM teachers.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goals of the UALRTeach Noyce Scholarship program are to recruit, train, and increase the retention of STEM teachers; increase the number and diversity of candidates seeking teacher licensure; and develop these candidates into teacher leaders.  To achieve these goals, it is vital to properly prepare scholars for their teaching experiences.  To this end, the Noyce Scholars Program placed candidates in classrooms early and often allowing them to apply prior knowledge and expand their pedagogical practice through experiential learning with classroom students.  Scholars were teamed with highly qualified mentor teachers in the student's discipline to observe effective teaching techniques and classroom management skills; receive thoughtful feedback and coaching; and provide examples of working in supportive, diverse educational settings. In addition to observing their mentor teachers, Scholars also present engaging, inquiry-based lessons approximately every other week to the mentor teacher's class. An inquiry-based approach has been shown to increase student engagement and achievement.   These lessons are used to practice and strengthen the Scholars’ lesson planning ability, proficiency at matching standards, lesson delivery and classroom management skills.  Learning is best done by doing. Teacher candidates that use and practice these inquiry methods are more likely to employ them in their own classrooms.

Scholars were observed and assessed at least once per semester by their mentor teacher and at least once per year by program staff. These observations and comments were shared with the scholar to improve their teaching effectiveness.  During their non-teaching weeks, Noyce Scholars worked with program staff and mathematics and science specialists to prepare STEM-focused lessons for the following week.  These additional teaching experiences provide the practice, additional resources and increased confidence to improve candidates’ pedagogy and classroom management skills necessary to be successful in their career. 

We were able to certify 10 scholars that taught or are teaching in high need schools with two more currently completing their certification. Based on their perceptions of the UALRTeach Noyce Scholars program and preparedness in the domains of Planning, the Classroom Environment, Instruction, and Professional Responsibilities, the majority of students felt well prepared or very well prepared for their teaching career, giving an average scaled score greater than 8 out of 10 (with 10 being the highest score).
